author: RICHARD NEWMAN
title: ConnectOne raises $50M in capital from investors - Business
text:
ConnectOne Bancorp Inc. has received $50 million in new capital from institutional investors, in part to redeem more than $11 million in preferred stock the company issued several years ago to the U.S. Treasury.
The Englewood Cliffs-based parent company of ConnectOne Bank said Tuesday after U.S. markets closed that it completed a private placement of subordinated notes to raise the funds.
The company, which has 24 offices and about $3.5 billion in assets, will pay the investors a fixed rate of 5.75 percent a year for the first five years, during which the notes are "non-callable."
The subordinated debt is rated BBB-by the Kroll Bond Rating Agency, which is an investment-grade rating.
"To get an 'A' from me is hard," said Christopher Whalen, senior managing director of Kroll. "Triple B, that's not bad. Most of the banks we rated are in the Bs. I would say it's a very solid bank."
The holding company formerly known as Center Bancorp, which did not respond to a request for comment, said in its Tuesday news release that it will use the new funds to redeem the $11.25 million in preferred stock it issued in 2011 to the Treasury under the Small Business Lending Fund Program, which is part of the Small Business Jobs Act signed into law by President Obama in September 2010.
ConnectOne Bancorp is one of more than half a dozen New Jersey financial companies that took the government up on an offer to convert their Troubled Asset Relief Program funding into the small-business lending program. The shift potentially reduced the interest rates they had to pay to the government, depending on whether they met small-business lending goals.
But the benefits are temporary. According to program guidelines, the rate paid by participating banks to the government will rise from as low as 1 percent a year to 9 percent after 4 1/2 years.
Otherwise, the $50 million raised by ConnectOne will be used for "general corporate purposes, including but not limited to contributing capital to the bank and to fund future growth."
Raymond James & Associates Inc. and Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc. were the joint-placement agents for the offering.
